courseMetadata.description: From fundamentals to full-stack Python development - 73 comprehensive lessons

modules.title: The Absolute Basics
modules.description: Start your programming journey with Python fundamentals

content.body:
# What is Programming, Really? *Estimated time: 10 minutes* --- ## The Concept

Imagine you're teaching a very literal-minded friend how to make a peanut butter and jelly sandwich. You can't just say 'make a sandwich'‚Äîyou have to break it down into tiny, specific steps:

  1. Pick up the bread bag
  2. Open the bag
  3. Take out two slices of bread
  4. Place them on the counter
  5. Pick up the jar of peanut butter
  6. Twist the lid counter-clockwise to open it
  7. ...and so on

That's exactly what programming is.

A computer is like that very literal friend. It's incredibly fast and never gets tired, but it only does exactly what you tell it to do, in exactly the order you tell it. If you forget a step or put them in the wrong order, it won't figure it out‚Äîit'll either do the wrong thing or stop and say "I don't understand."

Python is the language you'll use to give these instructions. Just like English or Spanish is a language humans use to communicate, Python is a language humans use to communicate with computers.

The beautiful thing? Python was designed to be as close to plain English as possible, so it reads almost like a recipe or a set of instructions you'd give to a friend.

--- ## Code Example ```python # This is your first Python program! # The '#' symbol creates a comment - notes for humans that the computer ignores # Tell the computer to print (display) a message print("Hello, World!") # That's it! This simple instruction tells Python: # "Show the text 'Hello, World!' on the screen" ``` **Output:** ``` Hello, World! ``` --- ## Syntax Breakdown

Let's break down what just happened:

  • print() - This is a function (we'll learn more about these later). Think of it as a command or action word, like 'display' or 'show'. It tells Python: 'take whatever is inside the parentheses and show it to the user.'
  • ("Hello, World!") - The parentheses ( ) are like a lunchbox‚Äîthey carry the information that print needs. Inside, we have "Hello, World!" wrapped in quotes.
  • "Hello, World!" - The quotation marks tell Python: 'This is text (what programmers call a string), not a command.' Without quotes, Python would think Hello is a command and get confused.
  • # - Everything after a # on a line is a comment. Python completely ignores it. Comments are notes you leave for yourself or other programmers to explain what the code does.

Why does this matter? Because if you wrote print(Hello, World!) without quotes, Python would say 'Error! I don't know what Hello is!' The quotes are crucial.

--- ## Key Takeaways
  • Programming is like giving very detailed, step-by-step instructions to a computer
  • Python is a language designed to be readable and beginner-friendly
  • print() is your first Python command‚Äîit displays text on the screen
  • Text (strings) must be wrapped in quotation marks: "like this" or 'like this'
  • Comments (lines starting with #) are notes for humans‚ÄîPython ignores them
  • Python is case-sensitive: print works, but Print doesn't
--- ## Solution Explanation

How it works:

  1. print is the command that tells Python to display something
  2. The parentheses () contain what you want to display
  3. The quotation marks "" tell Python this is text (a string), not code
  4. You can write ANY text inside the quotes‚Äîit's your message!

For the bonus, you simply added another print() line. Python reads your code from top to bottom, so it displays the first message, then the second.

## Common Mistakes

‚ö†Ô∏è Common Sticking Points:

  1. Forgetting the quotation marks:

    print(Hello)  ‚ùå Wrong - Python thinks Hello is a variable
print("Hello")  ‚úÖ Correct - Python knows this is text

  2. Misspelling 'print':

    Print("Hello")  ‚ùå Wrong - capital P
PRINT("Hello")  ‚ùå Wrong - all caps
print("Hello")  ‚úÖ Correct - lowercase 'print'

    Python is case-sensitive! print and Print are different things.

  3. Forgetting the parentheses:

    print "Hello"  ‚ùå Wrong in Python 3
print("Hello")  ‚úÖ Correct

  4. Mixing up quote types mid-string:

    print("Hello')  ‚ùå Wrong - starts with " but ends with '
print("Hello")  ‚úÖ Correct - matching quotes
print('Hello')  ‚úÖ Also correct - single quotes work too!

Pro Tip: Both double quotes "" and single quotes '' work in Python, but you must be consistent within each string!

codeExamples.code:
# This is your first Python program!
# The '#' symbol creates a comment - notes for humans that the computer ignores

# Tell the computer to print (display) a message
print("Hello, World!")

# That's it! This simple instruction tells Python:
# "Show the text 'Hello, World!' on the screen"
codeExamples.explanation: Example for What is Programming, Really?

exercises.title: Practice: What is Programming, Really?
exercises.instructions:
Your Turn!

Now it's time to write your own code. In the code editor below, you'll see some starter code with blanks (shown as ____).

Your task: Replace the blanks to make Python print your own message.

  1. Replace ____ with the command that displays text
  2. Inside the parentheses, write your own message (remember the quotes!)
  3. Click 'Run Code' to see your message appear

Bonus Challenge: Add a second print() line to display a second message!
exercises.starterCode:
# Welcome to your first Python exercise!
# Replace the ____ below with the correct code

____("Your message here")

# Bonus: Add another print() line below to display a second message
exercises.solution:
# Welcome to your first Python exercise!
# Here's the solution!

print("Your message here")

# Bonus: Here's a second print statement
print("I'm learning Python!")

# You could have written ANY message, like:
# print("My name is Alice")
# print("Python is fun!")
# print("2025 is my year!")
hints:
Hint: The command to display text is print. Remember to keep the quotation marks around your message!

Your code should look like: print("Your message here")

content.body:
# Your First Python Playground *Estimated time: 12 minutes* --- ## The Concept

Before you can speak Python to a computer, you need a place where the computer can listen and respond. Think of it like this:

  • If you want to cook, you need a kitchen
  • If you want to paint, you need a canvas
  • If you want to write Python code, you need a development environment

Don't let that fancy term scare you! A 'development environment' is just a place where you write code and see what happens when you run it. It's your programming workspace.

For this course, you have two options:

  1. Use this website's built-in code editor (the easiest way to start)
  2. Use a web-based Python playground like Python.org's online shell or Replit

Later, when you're more comfortable, you might want to install Python on your own computer. But for now, let's keep it simple and use the tools that are already available in your web browser.

Think of it like learning to drive: You don't buy a car on day one. You use a driving school's car first, then get your own when you're ready. Same idea here!

--- ## Code Example ```python # Let's test that everything is working! # This code will perform a few simple tasks # 1. Display a welcome message print("üêç Welcome to your Python Playground!") # 2. Do some simple math print("Python can do math: 5 + 3 =", 5 + 3) # 3. Display multiple lines print("Python can:") print(" - Display text") print(" - Calculate numbers") print(" - And much, much more!") # 4. Celebrate! print("\nüéâ Your Python environment is working perfectly!") ``` **Output:** ``` üêç Welcome to your Python Playground! Python can do math: 5 + 3 = 8 Python can: - Display text - Calculate numbers - And much, much more! üéâ Your Python environment is working perfectly! ``` --- ## Syntax Breakdown

Let's examine some new things in this code:

  • print("text", 5 + 3) - You can print multiple things in one line! Separate them with commas. Python will display them with a space in between.

    print("The answer is", 42)  # Shows: The answer is 42

  • \n - This is a special code that means 'new line' or 'press Enter'. It's like hitting the Enter key in the middle of your text.

    print("Line 1\nLine 2")  # Shows two separate lines

  • 5 + 3 - When you write math without quotes, Python actually calculates it! The result (8) gets printed.

    print(5 + 3)     # Shows: 8
print("5 + 3")   # Shows: 5 + 3 (just text)

  • Emojis - Yes, Python supports emojis in strings! You can use them just like any other text. They make your output more fun and readable.

The key concept: Anything inside quotation marks is displayed exactly as written. Anything outside quotes (like 5 + 3) is executed as Python code.

--- ## Key Takeaways
  • You can use web-based Python environments (playgrounds) to write and run code without installing anything
  • print() can display multiple items separated by commas
  • \n creates a new line in your output
  • Math without quotes gets calculated; math in quotes is just text
  • Python can use emojis and special characters in strings
  • The asterisk (*) means multiplication in Python
  • Your code is personal‚Äîmake it yours!
--- ## Solution Explanation

Breaking down the solution:

  1. The greeting: We used an emoji (üëã) to make it friendly, followed by the name in quotes.

  2. The blank line: \n creates a new line, making the output easier to read. You could also just use print() with nothing inside to create a blank line.

  3. The hobby: This is just text in quotes‚Äîsimple!

  4. The age calculation: We used 25 * 12 WITHOUT quotes so Python actually does the math. The result (300) gets printed.

    print("I am", 25 * 12, "months old")  # Shows: I am 300 months old

  5. The fun fact: More text in quotes. You can write anything!

Your solution will look different because you used YOUR name, YOUR hobby, YOUR age, and YOUR fun fact. That's perfect! Programming is about making the computer do what YOU want.

## Common Mistakes

‚ö†Ô∏è Common Sticking Points:

  1. Putting math in quotes:

    print("25 * 12")  ‚ùå Shows: 25 * 12 (just text)
print(25 * 12)    ‚úÖ Shows: 300 (calculated)

    If you want Python to calculate, DON'T use quotes!

  2. Forgetting commas when printing multiple things:

    print("I am" 25 "years old")  ‚ùå Error!
print("I am", 25, "years old")  ‚úÖ Correct

  3. Confusing \n with /n:

    print("/n")   ‚ùå Wrong slash - just prints /n
print("\n")  ‚úÖ Correct - creates a new line

    It's a backslash (\), not a forward slash (/)!

  4. Overthinking it: Your message doesn't have to be perfect or fancy. The goal is to practice using print(), combining text and numbers, and seeing that it works!

Remember: There's no single "right answer" for this exercise‚Äîyour unique output is the right answer as long as the code runs without errors!

codeExamples.code:
# Let's test that everything is working!
# This code will perform a few simple tasks

# 1. Display a welcome message
print("üêç Welcome to your Python Playground!")

# 2. Do some simple math
print("Python can do math: 5 + 3 =", 5 + 3)

# 3. Display multiple lines
print("Python can:")
print("  - Display text")
print("  - Calculate numbers")
print("  - And much, much more!")

# 4. Celebrate!
print("\nüéâ Your Python environment is working perfectly!")
codeExamples.explanation: Example for Your First Python Playground

exercises.title: Practice: Your First Python Playground
exercises.instructions:
Your Mission: Create a program that introduces yourself!

Requirements:

  1. Print a welcome message with your name
  2. Print your favorite hobby or interest
  3. Use Python to calculate your age in months (your age √ó 12)
  4. Print a fun fact about yourself

Challenge yourself: Use \n to add blank lines between sections to make it easier to read!
exercises.starterCode:
# Create your introduction program!

# 1. Welcome message
print("____")  # Replace with a greeting and your name

# 2. Print a blank line for spacing
print("\n")

# 3. Your hobby
print("My favorite hobby is: ____")  # Fill in your hobby

# 4. Calculate your age in months
# If you're 25 years old, you'd write: print("I am", 25 * 12, "months old")
print("I am", ____ * 12, "months old")  # Replace ____ with your age

# 5. A fun fact
print("____")  # Add any fun fact about yourself!
exercises.solution:
# Create your introduction program!

# 1. Welcome message
print("üëã Hello! My name is Alex")

# 2. Print a blank line for spacing
print("\n")

# 3. Your hobby
print("My favorite hobby is: reading science fiction books")

# 4. Calculate age in months
print("I am", 25 * 12, "months old")

# 5. A fun fact
print("Fun fact: I can solve a Rubik's cube in under 2 minutes!")

# Bonus: Add a closing message
print("\nüöÄ I'm excited to learn Python!")
hints:
Hints:

  • For the welcome message, try something like: print("Hello! My name is Alex")
  • Remember to put text in quotation marks: "text goes here"
  • For math, you DON'T use quotes: 25 * 12 (not "25 * 12")
  • The asterisk (*) means multiplication in Python

content.body:
# Making the Computer Talk *Estimated time: 15 minutes* --- ## The Concept

Imagine you're at a drive-through restaurant. You pull up to the speaker and say your order. The speaker talks back: 'That'll be $8.50. Please pull forward.' Then you drive to the window, hand over your money, and receive your food.

That's a conversation! You give information, they respond. Back and forth.

In programming, we call this input and output:

  • Output = The computer talking to YOU (like displaying text on screen)
  • Input = YOU talking to the computer (like typing something)

So far, we've only done output with print(). Now we're going to learn input, which lets your program ask questions and wait for answers. This transforms your code from a one-way announcement into a two-way conversation!

Real-world examples:

  • When Netflix asks "Who's watching?" and you click your profile - that's input
  • When you type your password and hit Enter - that's input
  • When a game asks "What's your name?" and you type it - that's input

Now YOUR programs can do the same thing!

--- ## Code Example ```python # Let's create our first interactive program! # Output: Ask the user for their name print("Hello! What's your name?") # Input: Wait for the user to type their name and press Enter name = input() # Output: Greet them personally print("Nice to meet you,", name, "!") # Let's ask another question print("\nWhat's your favorite color?") color = input() # Respond print("Wow!", color, "is a great color!") ``` **Output:** ``` Hello! What's your name? [User types: Sarah] Nice to meet you, Sarah ! What's your favorite color? [User types: blue] Wow! blue is a great color! ``` --- ## Syntax Breakdown

Let's break down this new concept:

  • name = input() - This is a BIG moment! Let's unpack it:

    • input() - This is a function (like print()) that pauses your program and waits for the user to type something and press Enter
    • name = - This creates a variable (a labeled storage box) called name and puts whatever the user typed into that box

    Think of it like this: input() is like a mailbox. When mail arrives, you put it in a labeled envelope (name) so you can find it later.

  • Using the variable: Once you've stored something in a variable, you can use it anywhere!

    print("Nice to meet you,", name, "!")

    Python looks in the name box, finds "Sarah" (or whatever the user typed), and uses it.

  • The equals sign (=): In Python, = doesn't mean "equals" like in math. It means "store this value in this variable." We call it the assignment operator.

    color = input()  # Means: "Take whatever input() gets and store it in 'color'"
--- ## Key Takeaways
  • input() pauses your program and waits for the user to type something and press Enter
  • Variables are like labeled storage boxes that hold information
  • You create a variable with: variable_name = value
  • The = sign means "store this value" (not "equals" like in math)
  • Variable names should be descriptive: name, age, color (not x, y, z)
  • When using a variable in print(), DON'T put it in quotes
  • You can put the prompt text inside input(): input("Your question here: ")
  • Variables let you store information and reuse it throughout your program
--- ## Solution Explanation

How this works step-by-step:

  1. First interaction:

    print("What's your name?")
name = input()

    The program asks the question, then STOPS and waits. When you type "Alex" and press Enter, "Alex" gets stored in the variable called name.

  2. Second interaction:

    print("How old are you?")
age = input()

    Same thing! Asks, waits, stores the answer in age.

  3. Third interaction:

    print("What's your favorite food?")
food = input()

    One more time‚Äîstores the answer in food.

  4. Using all the stored information:

    print("\nNice to meet you,", name, "!")
print("You are", age, "years old and you love", food, "!")

    Now we use all three variables. Python looks up what's stored in each one and uses those values!

The magic: Variables let you store information and use it later. Without variables, the information would disappear as soon as it was entered!

## Common Mistakes

‚ö†Ô∏è Common Sticking Points:

  1. Putting quotes around variable names when using them:

    print("Nice to meet you,", "name", "!")  ‚ùå Shows: Nice to meet you, name !
print("Nice to meet you,", name, "!")   ‚úÖ Shows: Nice to meet you, Alex !

    When you want the VALUE stored in a variable, DON'T use quotes!

  2. Forgetting to store the input in a variable:

    print("What's your name?")
input()  ‚ùå Input is collected but immediately forgotten

print("What's your name?")
name = input()  ‚úÖ Input is stored in 'name' so you can use it later

  3. Trying to use a variable you haven't created:

    print("Hello,", username, "!")  ‚ùå Error: 'username' is not defined

# You need to create it first:
username = input("What's your name? ")
print("Hello,", username, "!")  ‚úÖ Works!

  4. Misspelling variable names:

    name = input("What's your name? ")
print("Hello,", nama, "!")  ‚ùå Error: 'nama' is not defined (should be 'name')

    Python is picky! name and Name and nama are all different variables.

Pro Tip: You can put the question INSIDE the input() parentheses:

name = input("What's your name? ")  # Asks and waits on the same line!
# This is often cleaner than using a separate print() statement

codeExamples.code:
# Let's create our first interactive program!

# Output: Ask the user for their name
print("Hello! What's your name?")

# Input: Wait for the user to type their name and press Enter
name = input()

# Output: Greet them personally
print("Nice to meet you,", name, "!")

# Let's ask another question
print("\nWhat's your favorite color?")
color = input()

# Respond
print("Wow!", color, "is a great color!")
codeExamples.explanation: Example for Making the Computer Talk

exercises.title: Practice: Making the Computer Talk
exercises.instructions:
Your Mission: Create a "Getting to Know You" program!

Your program should:

  1. Ask for the user's name and store it in a variable
  2. Ask for their age and store it in a variable
  3. Ask for their favorite food and store it in a variable
  4. Print a summary that uses ALL three pieces of information

Example output:

What's your name? Alex
How old are you? 25
What's your favorite food? pizza

Nice to meet you, Alex!
You are 25 years old and you love pizza!
That's awesome!
exercises.starterCode:
# Getting to Know You program

# Ask for name
print("What's your name?")
name = ____  # Get the user's input

# Ask for age
print("How old are you?")
____ = input()  # Create a variable called 'age' and store the input

# Ask for favorite food
____("What's your favorite food?")
food = ____

# Now create a summary using all three variables
print("\nNice to meet you,", ____, "!")
print("You are", age, "years old and you love", ____, "!")
print("That's awesome!")
exercises.solution:
# Getting to Know You program - SOLUTION

# Ask for name
print("What's your name?")
name = input()  # Get the user's input

# Ask for age
print("How old are you?")
age = input()  # Create a variable called 'age' and store the input

# Ask for favorite food
print("What's your favorite food?")
food = input()

# Now create a summary using all three variables
print("\nNice to meet you,", name, "!")
print("You are", age, "years old and you love", food, "!")
print("That's awesome!")
hints:
Hints:

  • To get user input, use: input()
  • To store it in a variable: variable_name = input()
  • To display text, use: print("your text")
  • To use a variable in print, just write its name without quotes: print(name)
  • The blanks should be filled with either input(), print, or variable names like name, age, or food

content.body:
# Mini-Project: A Conversation Program *Estimated time: 20 minutes* --- ## The Concept

Congratulations! You've learned the fundamentals of Python:

  • ‚úÖ How to display output with print()
  • ‚úÖ How to get input from users with input()
  • ‚úÖ How to store information in variables
  • ‚úÖ How to create clean, readable output with f-strings

Now it's time to put it all together in a real project!

Project Goal: Create an interactive chatbot that has a multi-turn conversation with the user.

Think of it like building with LEGO blocks:

You've been learning about individual blocks (print, input, variables, f-strings). Now we're going to snap them together to build something cool! Each block you've learned is simple on its own, but when combined, they can create something that feels almost magical.

What makes a good conversation program?

  1. It's personal - Uses the person's name and remembers what they said
  2. It's engaging - Asks interesting questions
  3. It's responsive - Reacts to what the user tells it
  4. It's polite - Greets and says goodbye

Your program will do all of these things!

--- ## Code Example ```python # Personal Assistant Chatbot - Example Project print("="*50) print(" WELCOME TO YOUR PERSONAL ASSISTANT") print("="*50) # Get to know the user name = input("\nHello! What's your name? ") print(f"\nNice to meet you, {name}!") # Ask about their day feeling = input(f"How are you feeling today, {name}? ") print(f"I'm glad you're feeling {feeling}!") # Get their age and calculate fun facts age = input("\nHow old are you? ") age_months = int(age) * 12 # Convert age to months age_days = int(age) * 365 # Approximate days lived print(f"\nWow! That means you've been alive for approximately:") print(f" üóìÔ∏è {age_months} months") print(f" üìÖ {age_days} days") # Future plans goal = input(f"\nWhat's one goal you have this year, {name}? ") print(f"That's awesome! I believe you can achieve {goal}!") # Favorite things fav_food = input("What's your favorite food? ") fav_color = input("What's your favorite color? ") # Summary print("\n" + "="*50) print(" CONVERSATION SUMMARY") print("="*50) print(f"Name: {name}") print(f"Age: {age} years old ({age_months} months!)") print(f"Feeling: {feeling}") print(f"Goal: {goal}") print(f"Favorite Food: {fav_food}") print(f"Favorite Color: {fav_color}") print("="*50) print(f"\nThank you for chatting with me, {name}!") print(f"I hope you enjoy some {fav_color} {fav_food} today!") print("Good luck with your goals! üöÄ") ``` **Output:** ``` ================================================== WELCOME TO YOUR PERSONAL ASSISTANT ================================================== Hello! What's your name? Emma Nice to meet you, Emma! How are you feeling today, Emma? excited I'm glad you're feeling excited! How old are you? 24 Wow! That means you've been alive for approximately: üóìÔ∏è 288 months üìÖ 8760 days What's one goal you have this year, Emma? learn Python That's awesome! I believe you can achieve learn Python! What's your favorite food? sushi What's your favorite color? blue ================================================== CONVERSATION SUMMARY ================================================== Name: Emma Age: 24 years old (288 months!) Feeling: excited Goal: learn Python Favorite Food: sushi Favorite Color: blue ================================================== Thank you for chatting with me, Emma! I hope you enjoy some blue sushi today! Good luck with your goals! üöÄ ``` --- ## Syntax Breakdown

This project introduces one new concept: converting text to numbers.

  • int(age) - This converts text to an integer (whole number).

    Why is this necessary? When you use input(), Python treats everything as text (a string), even if the user types a number.

    age = input("How old are you? ")  # If user types "24", age = "24" (text)
age_months = age * 12              # ‚ùå Error! Can't multiply text

age = input("How old are you? ")   # User types "24", age = "24" (text)
age_months = int(age) * 12         # ‚úÖ Works! int() converts "24" to 24 (number)

  • The int() function explained:

    • int is short for "integer" (a whole number)
    • It takes text that looks like a number and converts it to an actual number
    • int("24") ‚Üí 24
    • int("100") ‚Üí 100

  • Using the converted number:

    age_months = int(age) * 12
age_days = int(age) * 365

    Now we can do math! * means multiply, so if age is 24: - 24 * 12 = 288 months - 24 * 365 = 8,760 days

  • Everything else: The rest is just clever use of what you already know:

    • Variables to remember information
    • F-strings to create personalized messages
    • String multiplication ("="*50) for decorative lines
    • Good prompts to make the conversation natural
--- ## Key Takeaways
  • You can combine print(), input(), variables, and f-strings to create interactive programs
  • input() always returns text (a string), even if the user types a number
  • Use int() to convert text to a whole number before doing math
  • Good programs are more than just question-and-answer‚Äîthey process information and provide value
  • Planning your program's structure before coding makes it easier to build
  • Visual formatting (lines, spacing, emojis) makes output more readable and engaging
  • Using variables lets you reference information throughout your program
  • The best programs reflect your creativity and interests!

üéâ Congratulations!
You've completed Module 1! You now understand:
‚Ä¢ What programming is
‚Ä¢ How to use Python basics
‚Ä¢ How to create interactive programs

You're ready to learn about storing and organizing information in Module 2!

--- ## Solution Explanation

Why this solution works:

  1. Clear theme: The program has a focused purpose (future planning) that makes it interesting and useful.

  2. Good prompts: Each question is clear and explains what information is needed.

  3. Multiple calculations:

    age_100 = int(current_year) + (100 - int(age))
years_to_milestone = int(milestone_age) - int(age)
milestone_year = int(current_year) + years_to_milestone

    These calculations make the program feel smart and helpful!

  4. Personalization: The program uses {name} multiple times to make it feel personal and engaging.

  5. Visual structure: Lines made with "="*50, section headers, and emojis make the output easy to read and fun.

  6. Meaningful content: Instead of just echoing back what the user said, the program provides new information (calculated years, milestones).

Remember: Your solution should look different! This is just one example. The best programs are the ones that reflect YOUR interests and creativity.

## Common Mistakes

‚ö†Ô∏è Common Sticking Points:

  1. Forgetting to convert strings to integers before math:

    age = input("Age: ")  # age = "24" (text)
future = age + 10     # ‚ùå Error! Can't add number to text

age = input("Age: ")
future = int(age) + 10  # ‚úÖ Works! Converts to number first

  2. Converting variables that aren't numbers:

    name = input("Name: ")  # User types "Emma"
result = int(name)      # ‚ùå Error! Can't convert "Emma" to a number

    Only use int() on variables that contain numbers!

  3. Not having enough questions: The requirement is at least 5 questions. Make sure you're asking enough to create an engaging conversation!

  4. Making the program too simple: Don't just collect information and repeat it. DO SOMETHING with it!

    • ‚ùå Bad: Ask for age, then just print the age
    • ‚úÖ Good: Ask for age, calculate age in months/days/future years

  5. Forgetting the summary: The summary section should display ALL the information in an organized, visually appealing way.

  6. Not testing the program: Run your code with different inputs to make sure it works correctly!

Pro Tips:

  • Add comments to explain sections of your code
  • Use blank lines (print()) to space out your output
  • Test with different inputs to ensure your calculations work
  • Have fun! If you're not excited about your program's topic, choose a different one

codeExamples.code:
# Personal Assistant Chatbot - Example Project

print("="*50)
print("    WELCOME TO YOUR PERSONAL ASSISTANT")
print("="*50)

# Get to know the user
name = input("\nHello! What's your name? ")
print(f"\nNice to meet you, {name}!")

# Ask about their day
feeling = input(f"How are you feeling today, {name}? ")
print(f"I'm glad you're feeling {feeling}!")

# Get their age and calculate fun facts
age = input("\nHow old are you? ")
age_months = int(age) * 12  # Convert age to months
age_days = int(age) * 365   # Approximate days lived

print(f"\nWow! That means you've been alive for approximately:")
print(f"  üóìÔ∏è  {age_months} months")
print(f"  üìÖ  {age_days} days")

# Future plans
goal = input(f"\nWhat's one goal you have this year, {name}? ")
print(f"That's awesome! I believe you can achieve {goal}!")

# Favorite things
fav_food = input("What's your favorite food? ")
fav_color = input("What's your favorite color? ")

# Summary
print("\n" + "="*50)
print("           CONVERSATION SUMMARY")
print("="*50)
print(f"Name: {name}")
print(f"Age: {age} years old ({age_months} months!)")
print(f"Feeling: {feeling}")
print(f"Goal: {goal}")
print(f"Favorite Food: {fav_food}")
print(f"Favorite Color: {fav_color}")
print("="*50)

print(f"\nThank you for chatting with me, {name}!")
print(f"I hope you enjoy some {fav_color} {fav_food} today!")
print("Good luck with your goals! üöÄ")

exercises.title: Practice: Mini-Project: A Conversation Program
exercises.instructions:
Your Mission: Create your OWN conversation program! Make it unique and fun.

Requirements - your program must:

  1. Have a creative title/greeting
  2. Ask at least 5 different questions
  3. Store all answers in variables
  4. Use f-strings to create personalized responses
  5. Include at least ONE calculation (like the age example)
  6. Display a summary at the end using all the collected information
  7. Have a friendly goodbye message

Ideas to get you started:

  • A Travel Advisor: Ask where they want to go, their budget, how many days, etc.
  • A Future Teller: Ask their age, calculate what year they'll turn 100, etc.
  • A Recipe Helper: Ask for ingredients, calculate servings, etc.
  • A Fitness Buddy: Ask about exercise goals, calculate calories, etc.
  • A Study Planner: Ask about subjects, calculate study hours needed, etc.

Be creative! This is YOUR program. Make it about something YOU find interesting!
exercises.starterCode:
# My Conversation Program
# Created by: [Your Name]

# Create a title/greeting
print("="*50)
print("    YOUR CREATIVE TITLE HERE")
print("="*50)

# Start the conversation
# Ask your first question
question1 = input("\nYour first question here: ")

# Add more questions (you need at least 5 total!)


# Do a calculation with one of the answers
# Example: number_answer = int(question1) * 2


# Create a summary section
print("\n" + "="*50)
print("           SUMMARY")
print("="*50)
# Display all the information you collected


# Goodbye message
print("\nThank you for using [Your Program Name]!")
exercises.solution:
# Future Year Calculator - SAMPLE SOLUTION
# Created by: The Python Team

print("="*50)
print("    FUTURE YEAR CALCULATOR")
print("    Discover Your Future Milestones!")
print("="*50)

# Get user information
name = input("\nWhat's your name? ")
print(f"\nHello, {name}! Let's explore your future together.")

age = input("How old are you right now? ")
current_year = input("What year is it? ")

# Ask about goals
milestone_age = input("At what age would you like to achieve a major goal? ")
goal = input("What goal do you want to achieve? ")
favorite_place = input("What's your dream travel destination? ")

# Calculate future milestones
age_100 = int(current_year) + (100 - int(age))
years_to_milestone = int(milestone_age) - int(age)
milestone_year = int(current_year) + years_to_milestone

# Create an exciting summary
print("\n" + "="*50)
print("        YOUR FUTURE MILESTONES")
print("="*50)
print(f"Name: {name}")
print(f"Current Age: {age} years old")
print(f"Current Year: {current_year}")
print("\n--- EXCITING PREDICTIONS ---")
print(f"üéÇ You'll turn 100 in the year {age_100}!")
print(f"üéØ In {years_to_milestone} years (year {milestone_year}),")
print(f"   you'll be {milestone_age} and achieve: {goal}")
print(f"‚úàÔ∏è  Don't forget to visit {favorite_place}!")
print("="*50)

print(f"\nAmazing, {name}! The future is bright! üåü")
print(f"Start working towards {goal} today!")
print("\nThank you for using the Future Year Calculator!")
print("Good luck on your journey! üöÄ")
hints:
Hints:

  • Structure your program in sections:
    1. Title/Greeting
    2. Questions (5+ with good prompts)
    3. Calculations (at least 1)
    4. Summary
    5. Goodbye
  • For calculations: Use int(variable_name) to convert text to a number first
  • Make it personal: Use the user's name throughout the conversation
  • Use f-strings: f"Thanks, {name}! You said {answer}."
  • Add decorative elements: "="*50, emojis, spacing with \n
  • Test your program: Run it yourself first to make sure it makes sense!

modules.title: Storing & Using Information
modules.description: Learn how to work with variables and data

content.body:
# The Labeled Box (Variables Explained) *Estimated time: 15 minutes* --- ## The Concept

Imagine you're moving into a new apartment. You have lots of boxes, but if they're not labeled, you'll never find anything! You need to write on each box:

  • üì¶ 'Kitchen Stuff'
  • üì¶ 'Books'
  • üì¶ 'Clothes'
  • üì¶ 'Electronics'

Now when you need a specific item, you know exactly which box to open.

Variables work exactly like labeled moving boxes!

A variable is a container that stores information, and you give it a name (label) so you can find that information later. Without variables, your program would forget everything immediately‚Äîlike having boxes with no labels!

Real-world analogy:

  • Your phone saves contacts with names (variables): 'Mom', 'Best Friend', 'Pizza Place'
  • Without names, you'd just have a list of random numbers‚Äîimpossible to use!
  • The name 'Mom' points to a phone number, just like a variable name points to a value

In Python, you create a variable by giving it a name and assigning it a value using the equals sign (=).

--- ## Code Example ```python # Creating variables - like labeling boxes # A variable that stores text (a person's name) name = "Sarah" # A variable that stores a number (age) age = 28 # A variable that stores a decimal number (price) price = 19.99 # A variable that stores a True/False value is_student = True # Now let's use these variables print("Customer Information:") print(f"Name: {name}") print(f"Age: {age}") print(f"Item Price: ${price}") print(f"Student Discount Eligible: {is_student}") # You can change what's in a variable (relabel the box) age = 29 # Happy birthday! print(f"\nUpdated Age: {age}") ``` **Output:** ``` Customer Information: Name: Sarah Age: 28 Item Price: $19.99 Student Discount Eligible: True Updated Age: 29 ``` --- ## Syntax Breakdown

Let's understand the rules for creating and using variables:

  • Creating a variable: variable_name = value

    name = "Sarah"  # Create a variable called 'name', put "Sarah" in it

    The = sign is like a label maker. It says: "From now on, whenever I say 'name', I mean 'Sarah'."

  • Variable naming rules:

    1. Can contain letters, numbers, and underscores: my_age_2 ‚úÖ
    2. Must start with a letter or underscore, NOT a number: age2 ‚úÖ, 2age ‚ùå
    3. Cannot contain spaces: user_name ‚úÖ, user name ‚ùå
    4. Case-sensitive: Name and name are different variables
    5. Cannot use Python keywords (like print, if, for)

  • Good variable names are descriptive:

    # Bad - what does 'x' mean?
x = 25

# Good - clearly stores someone's age
age = 25

  • Changing a variable's value:

    score = 100   # Start with 100
score = 150   # Change it to 150
# The old value (100) is gone; score now holds 150

    It's like taking items out of a labeled box and putting different items in!

--- ## Key Takeaways
  • Variables are like labeled boxes that store information
  • Create a variable with: variable_name = value
  • Variable names should be descriptive: age not x
  • Variable naming rules: start with letter, no spaces, use underscores
  • Text (strings) needs quotes: "Sarah"
  • Numbers don't need quotes: 25
  • True/False are special values (Booleans): True, False
  • You can change a variable's value anytime
  • Good variable names make your code readable and maintainable
--- ## Solution Explanation

Understanding the solution:

  1. Creating variables with different types of data:

    • first_name = "Alex" - Text (string) in quotes
    • age = 25 - Number (integer) without quotes
    • likes_pizza = True - Boolean (True/False) without quotes

  2. Using variables in calculations:

    age_in_months = age * 12

    We can use the value stored in age to calculate something new!

  3. Combining variables in f-strings:

    print(f"Name: {first_name} {last_name}")

    We can use multiple variables in one string!

  4. Updating variables:

    age = 26  # Old value (25) is replaced with new value (26)

    When you change a variable, you need to recalculate anything that depends on it!

## Common Mistakes

‚ö†Ô∏è Common Sticking Points:

  1. Putting quotes around numbers:

    age = "25"  ‚ùå This is text, not a number!
age = 25    ‚úÖ This is a number you can use in math

  2. Forgetting quotes around text:

    name = Sarah  ‚ùå Python looks for a variable called Sarah
name = "Sarah"  ‚úÖ This creates text

  3. Wrong capitalization for True/False:

    likes_pizza = true   ‚ùå Lowercase doesn't work
likes_pizza = TRUE   ‚ùå All caps doesn't work
likes_pizza = True   ‚úÖ Must have capital T

  4. Using variable names that don't exist:

    # You created: favorite_number = 7
print(f"Number: {fav_num}")  ‚ùå 'fav_num' was never created!
print(f"Number: {favorite_number}")  ‚úÖ Correct name

  5. Not updating related calculations:

    age = 25
age_in_months = age * 12  # 300
age = 26  # Changed age
# age_in_months is still 300! Need to recalculate it!

codeExamples.code:
# Creating variables - like labeling boxes

# A variable that stores text (a person's name)
name = "Sarah"

# A variable that stores a number (age)
age = 28

# A variable that stores a decimal number (price)
price = 19.99

# A variable that stores a True/False value
is_student = True

# Now let's use these variables
print("Customer Information:")
print(f"Name: {name}")
print(f"Age: {age}")
print(f"Item Price: ${price}")
print(f"Student Discount Eligible: {is_student}")

# You can change what's in a variable (relabel the box)
age = 29  # Happy birthday!
print(f"\nUpdated Age: {age}")
codeExamples.explanation: Example for The Labeled Box (Variables Explained)

exercises.instructions:
Your Mission: Create a profile card for yourself using variables!

Requirements:

  1. Create variables for:
    • Your first name
    • Your last name
    • Your age
    • Your favorite number
    • Whether you like pizza (True or False)
    • Your city
  2. Use f-strings to display all this information in a nicely formatted profile
  3. Calculate and display your age in months
  4. Change one variable and print the updated value
exercises.starterCode:
# Personal Profile Card

# Create your variables
first_name = "____"  # Your first name
last_name = "____"   # Your last name
age = ____           # Your age (number, no quotes)
favorite_number = ____
likes_pizza = ____   # True or False (no quotes)
city = "____"

# Calculate age in months
age_in_months = age * 12

# Display your profile
print("=" * 40)
print("       PERSONAL PROFILE CARD")
print("=" * 40)
print(f"Name: {first_name} {last_name}")
print(f"Age: {age} years ({age_in_months} months)")
print(f"City: {____}")
print(f"Favorite Number: {____}")
print(f"Likes Pizza: {____}")
print("=" * 40)

# Update one variable
age = ____  # Change your age
print(f"\nUpdated Age: {age}")
exercises.solution:
# Personal Profile Card - SOLUTION

# Create your variables
first_name = "Alex"
last_name = "Johnson"
age = 25
favorite_number = 7
likes_pizza = True
city = "Portland"

# Calculate age in months
age_in_months = age * 12

# Display your profile
print("=" * 40)
print("       PERSONAL PROFILE CARD")
print("=" * 40)
print(f"Name: {first_name} {last_name}")
print(f"Age: {age} years ({age_in_months} months)")
print(f"City: {city}")
print(f"Favorite Number: {favorite_number}")
print(f"Likes Pizza: {likes_pizza}")
print("=" * 40)

# Update one variable
age = 26  # Birthday!
age_in_months = age * 12  # Recalculate
print(f"\nUpdated Age: {age} years ({age_in_months} months)")
hints:
Hints:

  • Text values need quotes: "Sarah"
  • Numbers DON'T need quotes: 25
  • True and False are special values (no quotes, capital first letter): True or False
  • To use a variable in an f-string: f"Text {variable_name} more text"
  • Make sure all variable names in the print statements match the names you created above!

lessons.title: Different Kinds of Boxes (Data Types: Strings, Integers, Floats)

content.body:
# Different Kinds of Boxes (Data Types: Strings, Integers, Floats) *Estimated time: 18 minutes* --- ## The Concept

Imagine you're organizing your garage. You have different types of containers for different things:

  • üì¶ Cardboard boxes for storing books and papers (fragile text items)
  • üß∞ Plastic bins with numbers for counting screws and nails (whole numbers)
  • ‚öñÔ∏è Containers with measurement scales for liquids like paint (precise amounts with decimals)
  • ‚úÖ Yes/No labels for items that are either here or not (True/False)

You wouldn't store liquid paint in a cardboard box, right? And you wouldn't count screws with a measuring cup. You use the right container for the right type of thing.

Python works the same way! It has different "types" of data, and each type is suited for a specific purpose:

  • Strings (str) - Text and words. Like labels on boxes: "Hello", "Sarah", "123 Main St"
  • Integers (int) - Whole numbers for counting. Like counting screws: 5, 100, -42
  • Floats (float) - Numbers with decimal points for precise measurements. Like measuring paint: 3.14, 19.99, -0.5
  • Booleans (bool) - True or False values. Like yes/no questions: True, False

Why does this matter?

Because you can't do math with text, and you can't make "HELLO" uppercase if it's a number! Python needs to know what kind of data you're working with so it knows what operations make sense.

Think of it like this: if someone hands you a container, you need to know if it holds text, numbers, or true/false values before you know what you can do with it.

--- ## Code Example ```python # Let's explore Python's main data types! # STRING - text wrapped in quotes name = "Alice" greeting = 'Hello, World!' address = "123 Main Street" print("STRINGS (text):") print(f"name = {name}") print(f"Type: {type(name)}") print() # INTEGER - whole numbers (no quotes, no decimal point) age = 25 students = 100 temperature = -5 print("INTEGERS (whole numbers):") print(f"age = {age}") print(f"Type: {type(age)}") print() # FLOAT - numbers with decimal points price = 19.99 pi = 3.14159 temperature_precise = 98.6 print("FLOATS (decimal numbers):") print(f"price = {price}") print(f"Type: {type(price)}") print() # BOOLEAN - True or False (capital T and F, no quotes) is_student = True has_license = False print("BOOLEANS (True/False):") print(f"is_student = {is_student}") print(f"Type: {type(is_student)}") print() # What happens when you mix types? print("MIXING TYPES:") print(f"String + String: {'Hello' + ' ' + 'World'}") print(f"Integer + Integer: {10 + 5}") print(f"Float + Integer: {3.5 + 2}") print(f"String * Integer: {'Ha' * 3}") # print(f"String + Integer: {'Age: ' + 25}") # This would cause an ERROR! ``` **Output:** ``` STRINGS (text): name = Alice Type: INTEGERS (whole numbers): age = 25 Type: FLOATS (decimal numbers): price = 19.99 Type: BOOLEANS (True/False): is_student = True Type: MIXING TYPES: String + String: Hello World Integer + Integer: 15 Float + Integer: 5.5 String * Integer: HaHaHa ``` --- ## Syntax Breakdown

Let's break down each data type and understand the rules:

1. Strings (str) - The Text Type

  • What they are: Any text wrapped in quotes (single ' or double ")

    name = "Alice"     # Double quotes
greeting = 'Hi!'   # Single quotes (works the same)
message = "123"    # Even numbers in quotes are strings!

  • Key rule: MUST have matching quotes at start and end

    "Hello"  ‚úÖ Correct
'Hello'  ‚úÖ Also correct
"Hello'  ‚ùå Error - quotes don't match!

  • The type() function: Tells you what type a value is

    print(type("Alice"))  # Shows:

    Think of type() as asking "What kind of container is this?"

2. Integers (int) - The Whole Number Type

  • What they are: Whole numbers with NO decimal point and NO quotes

    age = 25        # Positive integer
count = 0       # Zero is an integer
debt = -500     # Negative integer

  • Key rule: NO quotes, NO decimal point

    age = 25       ‚úÖ Integer
age = "25"     ‚ùå String (has quotes)
age = 25.0     ‚ùå Float (has decimal point)

  • You can do math: +, -, *, /, //, %, **

    students = 20 + 5   # Addition: 25
groups = 20 // 5    # Division (whole number): 4
squared = 5 ** 2    # Exponent: 25

3. Floats (float) - The Decimal Number Type

  • What they are: Numbers with a decimal point

    price = 19.99
pi = 3.14159
temperature = -2.5
exact_value = 5.0  # Even whole numbers with .0 are floats!

  • Key rule: MUST have a decimal point (even if it's .0)

    price = 19.99  ‚úÖ Float
price = 20     ‚ùå Integer (no decimal point)

  • Mixing int and float: Result is always a float

    result = 5 + 2.5   # 5 (int) + 2.5 (float) = 7.5 (float)
print(type(result))  #

  • IEEE 754 Standard: Python uses 64-bit precision for floats (about 15-17 decimal digits of accuracy)

4. Booleans (bool) - The True/False Type

  • What they are: Only TWO possible values: True or False

    is_raining = True
has_license = False

  • Key rules:

    1. Must be capitalized: True and False (not true or false)
    2. NO quotes (with quotes they become strings)
    is_student = True    ‚úÖ Boolean
is_student = true    ‚ùå Error (not capitalized)
is_student = "True"  ‚ùå String (has quotes)

5. Mixing Types - What Works and What Doesn't

OperationExampleResult
String + String"Hello" + " World"‚úÖ "Hello World"
Integer + Integer5 + 3‚úÖ 8
Float + Integer5.5 + 2‚úÖ 7.5
String * Integer"Ha" * 3‚úÖ "HaHaHa"
String + Integer"Age: " + 25‚ùå TypeError!

The golden rule: You can't directly combine strings and numbers with +. You need to convert them first (we'll learn this next lesson!).

--- ## Key Takeaways
  • Python has four main basic data types: str (strings), int (integers), float (decimals), and bool (True/False)
  • Strings are text in quotes: "Hello" or 'Hello'
  • Integers are whole numbers without quotes: 42, -5, 0
  • Floats are decimal numbers: 3.14, 19.99, -2.5
  • Booleans are True or False (capitalized, no quotes)
  • Use type(variable) to check what type of data a variable holds
  • You can do math with integers and floats, but NOT directly with strings
  • Mixing int and float in math gives you a float result
  • You CAN multiply a string by an integer to repeat it: "Hi" * 3 = "HiHiHi"
  • Each type has its own "rules" and "superpowers" - use the right type for the right job!
  • Python follows IEEE 754 standard for floats (64-bit, ~15-17 decimal digits precision)
--- ## Solution Explanation

Breaking down the solution:

  1. Creating variables with different types:

    player_name = "DragonSlayer"  # String - has quotes
player_level = 42             # Integer - whole number, no quotes
health_points = 87.5          # Float - has decimal point
is_online = True              # Boolean - True/False, capitalized

    Each variable holds a different type of data, like different containers in your garage!

  2. Using type() to check data types:

    print(type(player_name))  # Output:

    The type() function is like asking Python: "What kind of container is this?" It returns the data type.

  3. Math with integers:

    next_level = player_level + 1  # 42 + 1 = 43

    You can do math with integers and floats. Python handles it automatically!

  4. String multiplication:

    battle_cry = "Victory" * 3  # "VictoryVictoryVictory"

    Multiplying a string by an integer repeats the string. This ONLY works with strings and integers - not string + integer!

  5. Float calculations:

    health_percent = (health_points / max_health) * 100
# (87.5 / 100.0) * 100 = 87.5

    Dividing floats gives you precise decimal results. Perfect for percentages!

  6. String methods (bonus):

    player_name.upper()  # "DRAGONSLAYER"

    Strings have built-in "methods" (special functions) like .upper(), .lower(), etc. We'll explore these more later!

Key Insight: Each data type has its own "superpowers":

  • Strings can be made uppercase/lowercase, sliced, concatenated
  • Integers and Floats can be used in math operations
  • Booleans are perfect for yes/no decisions (you'll use these LOTS in Module 3!)
## Common Mistakes

‚ö†Ô∏è Common Sticking Points:

  1. Putting quotes around numbers when you want to do math:

    age = "25"       # ‚ùå This is a STRING
age = age + 1    # ‚ùå Error! Can't add number to string

age = 25         # ‚úÖ This is an INTEGER
age = age + 1    # ‚úÖ Works! Result: 26

    Rule: If you plan to do math, DON'T use quotes!

  2. Forgetting the decimal point for floats:

    price = 20       # This is an INTEGER (20)
price = 20.0     # This is a FLOAT (20.0)

# They look similar but are different types!
print(type(20))    # 
print(type(20.0))  #

  3. Wrong capitalization for booleans:

    is_ready = true    ‚ùå Error: 'true' is not defined
is_ready = TRUE    ‚ùå Error: 'TRUE' is not defined
is_ready = True    ‚úÖ Correct - capital T
is_ready = False   ‚úÖ Correct - capital F

    Python is case-sensitive! True and False are keywords, not variables.

  4. Trying to add strings and numbers directly:

    # ‚ùå This doesn't work:
print("Age: " + 25)  # TypeError: can only concatenate str to str

# ‚úÖ Solutions:
print("Age:", 25)           # Use comma (adds space automatically)
print(f"Age: {25}")         # Use f-string
print("Age: " + str(25))    # Convert to string first (next lesson!)

  5. Confusing / and //:

    result = 10 / 3    # Regular division: 3.3333... (float)
result = 10 // 3   # Floor division: 3 (integer, rounds down)

print(type(10 / 3))   # 
print(type(10 // 3))  #

  6. Thinking type() changes the type:

    age = "25"
print(type(age))  # ‚ùå This just CHECKS the type, doesn't change it!

age = int(age)    # ‚úÖ This CONVERTS it (we'll learn this in Lesson 3!)

    type() is like looking at a label - it doesn't change what's inside!

Pro Tip: When in doubt, use print(type(your_variable)) to check what type you're working with. It's like asking Python "What kind of box is this?" before you try to use it!

codeExamples.code:
# Let's explore Python's main data types!

# STRING - text wrapped in quotes
name = "Alice"
greeting = 'Hello, World!'
address = "123 Main Street"

print("STRINGS (text):")
print(f"name = {name}")
print(f"Type: {type(name)}")
print()

# INTEGER - whole numbers (no quotes, no decimal point)
age = 25
students = 100
temperature = -5

print("INTEGERS (whole numbers):")
print(f"age = {age}")
print(f"Type: {type(age)}")
print()

# FLOAT - numbers with decimal points
price = 19.99
pi = 3.14159
temperature_precise = 98.6

print("FLOATS (decimal numbers):")
print(f"price = {price}")
print(f"Type: {type(price)}")
print()

# BOOLEAN - True or False (capital T and F, no quotes)
is_student = True
has_license = False

print("BOOLEANS (True/False):")
print(f"is_student = {is_student}")
print(f"Type: {type(is_student)}")
print()

# What happens when you mix types?
print("MIXING TYPES:")
print(f"String + String: {'Hello' + ' ' + 'World'}")
print(f"Integer + Integer: {10 + 5}")
print(f"Float + Integer: {3.5 + 2}")
print(f"String * Integer: {'Ha' * 3}")
# print(f"String + Integer: {'Age: ' + 25}")  # This would cause an ERROR!
codeExamples.explanation: Example for Different Kinds of Boxes (Data Types: Strings, Integers, Floats)

exercises.title: Practice: Different Kinds of Boxes (Data Types: Strings, Integers, Floats)
exercises.instructions:
Your Mission: Create a "Player Profile" program that demonstrates all four data types!

Requirements:

  1. Create variables for:
    • Player name (string)
    • Player level (integer)
    • Health points (float)
    • Is online (boolean)
  2. Use type() to verify each variable's type
  3. Display a formatted profile showing all the information
  4. Perform at least one math operation with numbers
  5. Try multiplying a string by an integer

Bonus Challenge: Calculate the player's health percentage (current health / max health * 100) and display it!
exercises.starterCode:
# Player Profile Program

# Create your variables (replace the ____ )
player_name = "____"        # A string (use quotes)
player_level = ____         # An integer (no quotes, no decimal)
health_points = ____        # A float (use decimal point)
is_online = ____            # True or False (no quotes, capital T/F)

# Display the profile
print("=" * 40)
print("       PLAYER PROFILE")
print("=" * 40)
print(f"Name: {player_name}")
print(f"Level: {player_level}")
print(f"Health: {health_points} HP")
print(f"Status: {'Online' if is_online else 'Offline'}")
print("=" * 40)

# Check the types
print("\nDATA TYPES:")
print(f"player_name type: {type(____)}")     # Fill in the variable name
print(f"player_level type: {type(____)}")   # Fill in the variable name
print(f"health_points type: {type(____)}")  # Fill in the variable name
print(f"is_online type: {type(____)}")      # Fill in the variable name

# Do some math
next_level = player_level + ____  # Add 1 to level
print(f"\nNext level will be: {next_level}")

# String multiplication
battle_cry = "____" * 3  # Repeat any word 3 times
print(f"Battle cry: {battle_cry}")

# BONUS: Calculate health percentage
max_health = 100.0  # Maximum health
health_percent = (health_points / max_health) * 100
print(f"\nHealth: {health_percent}%")
exercises.solution:
# Player Profile Program - SOLUTION

# Create your variables
player_name = "DragonSlayer"    # String
player_level = 42               # Integer
health_points = 87.5            # Float
is_online = True                # Boolean

# Display the profile
print("=" * 40)
print("       PLAYER PROFILE")
print("=" * 40)
print(f"Name: {player_name}")
print(f"Level: {player_level}")
print(f"Health: {health_points} HP")
print(f"Status: {'Online' if is_online else 'Offline'}")
print("=" * 40)

# Check the types
print("\nDATA TYPES:")
print(f"player_name type: {type(player_name)}")
print(f"player_level type: {type(player_level)}")
print(f"health_points type: {type(health_points)}")
print(f"is_online type: {type(is_online)}")

# Do some math
next_level = player_level + 1
print(f"\nNext level will be: {next_level}")

# String multiplication
battle_cry = "Victory" * 3
print(f"Battle cry: {battle_cry}")

# BONUS: Calculate health percentage
max_health = 100.0
health_percent = (health_points / max_health) * 100
print(f"\nHealth: {health_percent}%")

# Additional examples:
print("\n--- EXTRA EXAMPLES ---")
print(f"Level squared: {player_level ** 2}")
print(f"Half health: {health_points / 2}")
print(f"Name in uppercase: {player_name.upper()}")
hints:
Hints:

  • Strings: Use quotes: "DragonSlayer"
  • Integers: Whole numbers, no quotes: 25
  • Floats: Include decimal point: 87.5
  • Booleans: Capital T or F, no quotes: True
  • type(): Put the variable name inside: type(player_name)
  • String multiplication: "Attack" * 3 gives "AttackAttackAttack"
  • For the ternary operator (if...else in the print statement), just leave it as is - it's a preview of what you'll learn in Module 3!
